--- In neat@yahoogroups.com, "Wesley Tansey" <tansey@...> wrote:
>
> Hi Ken=
,
> 
>  
> 
> > I think this idea of having a healthy range of sizes is les=
s prevalent
> > in GP because GP populations are usually not speciated and =
therefore
> > tend to bloat all at once. As soon as someone gets bigger, he=
 starts
> > mating with others and spreading the extra genes around. Theref=
ore,
> > GP doesn't tend to keep a healthy range the way NEAT does. We
> > =
actually have built a version of GP-NEAT at EPlex (which has
> > historical=
 markings and speciation, but with GP trees) that has very
> > different bl=
oat characteristics than regular GP, as this argument
> > would suggest.
> =

> 
> 
> That sounds very interesting.  Would you mind sharing some of the
=
results
> with us? Also, is the code publicly available for download?
> 
> =
 
> 
> Wesley
> 
> 
> 

Wesley, unfortunately GP-NEAT is not available for =
download and we
don't have any publications released on it.  Adelein Rodrig=
uez built
it as part of her Masters project at UCF, and has since graduated=
. 
But I am hoping that we manage to get out a publication and at the
same =
time release the software at some point.  It just got pushed back
by a few =
other things, which is too bad since it's a nice piece of
work.  It's actua=
lly very tricky to get real NEAT-like functionality
working with GP, but Ad=
elein did it and it's really a new type of GP.

ken
